Steps to reproduce:

1) Check "Allow multiple modules per project" in the preferences.
2) Create a Dynamic Web Project.
3) Add a second module to that project.
4) Create a second Dynamic Web Project.
5) In J2EE view or a navigator, select the second Dynamic Web Project.
6) Execute New->Web->Servlet, which should have the second project default 
selected.
7) Select the first Dynamic Web Project, NPE.

With revision 1.18 of NewJavaClassWizardPage I get:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at 
org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.wizard.NewJavaClassWizardPage.initializeComponent
List(NewJavaClassWizardPage.java:222)
at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.wizard.NewJavaClassWizardPage.access$1
(NewJavaClassWizardPage.java:196)
at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.wizard.NewJavaClassWizardPage$2.widgetSelected
(NewJavaClassWizardPage.java:243)
...

The return value of "WebPropertiesUtil.getJavaSourceFolder(project)", which is 
used without checking, returns null because it wants a single source folder 
and gets two because the project has two modules.  I don't know if other 
wizards might trip of this problem too.

This is switched to use the virtual component API and is null blocked.

Fixed for the 0712 WTP I build.

I have verified that the NPE no longer occurs in I20050713, so I'm marking this 
one VERIFIED.  However, behavior of the Servlet Wizard is now rather odd.  
The "Folder:" field doesn't change for example when the project is changed.  I 
have entered a new bug (#103661) to report the odd behavior.  The odd behavior 
may be related to the changes you made, though I suspect is comes more from 
issues in what your changes use (rather than how you wrote your changes).  It 
may be helpful to look at this new bug to determine how your changes may be 
contributing.  Unfortunately, I haven't found time yet to dig into this.
